Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Biomechanical significance of bone material variation in the locomotor skeleton

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
While it is recognized that bone health is influenced by physical activity, it remains unclear whether it is the intensity, duration, or frequency of activity that has the most positive impact on skeletal integrity. This research investigates how the skeleton of primates (such as humans) adapts to physical activity through examination of the differential impact of diverse forms of locomotor behavior on multiple measures of bone anatomy. The integrated approach requires a study population for which the requisite behavioral, biomechanical, and bone structure data are accessible; the bone samples examined therefore come from a population of seven African primate species for which locomotor behavior and activity patterns have been under study for over 15 years, providing a unique and broad spectrum of behavioral variation from which to investigate how bones respond to different activity regimens. Through examination of these interrelationships, the research will improve understanding of the influence of physiological activity (e.g., intensity and frequency of running) on bone structure and adaptation, and thereby identify the types of activity that influence the integrity of limb bones.

The study combines consideration of bone quantity (size) with quality (stiffness) to calculate measures of bone structural integrity. Bone quality is determined through the technique of microindentation, a method that measures small-scale variation in bone stiffness throughout bones to permit detailed understanding of bone strength, including fracture risk. In addition, how different types of locomotor activity (walking, running, jumping) and activity levels (amount of time spent per day in locomotion) influence bone adaptation is assessed through the different perspectives of kinetics (the measurement of forces on the skeleton) and remodeling (the process by which bone repairs itself). Through this comparative and multifaceted approach, this research seeks to establish what aspects of physical activity are influential in either positively or negatively affecting bone strength.

The overarching intellectual merit of this study is that in determining the association between bone anatomy and locomotor behavior, the kinds of activity that can positively influence bone adaptation may be identified. Such results should find application to clinical contexts for human populations in establishing more definitive links between behavior and anatomy, and through refined assessments of bone quality that can be used as an index of bone health and function. In addition, several impacts of societal importance emerge from this research activity. These include interdisciplinary training in anthropology, engineering, and the health sciences for both undergraduate and graduate US students; inclusion of underrepresented groups in engineering and anthropological research; contributions to the conservation of threatened primate populations; and improvement of educational infrastructure at the university level across three US institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This work investigated the limb bones and locomotor behavior of seven primate species endemic to Côte d'Ivoire's Taï National Forest. These monkeys exhibit a wide array of activity in terms of the types and frequencies of locomotor patterns including walking, running, bounding, climbing and leaping. The purpose of this investigation was to relate the structural (size and shape) and material (architectural and compositional) properties of the limb bones to observed behavior, with a view toward understanding how activity patterns are associated with different measures of bone quality, including variables related to resilience and strength. To some degree, resilience and strength are inversely related, as reduced mineralization of bone material renders it more compliant, at a cost of reduced strength. Bone repair is thought to reduce the stiffness and strength of bone material, and its action can be documented by the presence of microscopic signatures of bone repair called osteons which indicate the replacement of old or damaged tissue with newer bone.

Leaping is a high-intensity activity that is practiced with varying frequencies by the Taï monkeys. Those species which leap the most were found to have more osteons in their thigh bones (femora) than species which leapt less frequently. The arm bones (humerus), however, showed no such differences among species but across species had a greater density of osteons compared to femoral bone. We hypothesize that the additional repaired bone in the arm is due to a greater frequency and variety of activities, such as feeding, foraging and grooming that is characteristic of all the species. This result suggests that bone repair is related more directly to frequency rather than intensity of activity.

Research on macaque skeletons compared several bones within the same individuals for signs of bone repair. This study found that weight-bearing bones of the thigh and leg have fewer osteons than ribs or non-weight bearing limb elements. This study reinforced the conclusion above that the magnitude of forces experienced in bones is not the only factor which governs bone repair. This finding supports the idea that bone cells use information about the frequency of forces applied to them to regulate bone repair.

A study of the thigh bones of two leaping monkeys revealed stiffer bone material in the species that leaped more and this species had reduced anisotropy (i.e., “grain”) as well. The more compliant bone material in the other species is associated with slimmer limb bones overall, which is thought to be related to observations that this species employs locomotor behaviors that involve reduced forces on the limbs.

In the context of the results summarized above, the intellectual merit of this study is that in, studying animals in which anatomical and behavioral data are known for the same natural populations, the relationship between activity variation and differences in bone quality can be evaluated. We explored the tradeoff between bone strength and resiliency through both mechanical testing and the microscopic signatures of bone repair. The data collected suggest that these tradeoffs are not pursued equivalently throughout the limbs, but are specific to the kinds of bones (i.e., those of the upper and lower limb, or arm and forearm) as well as certain regions within bones. An important component of physical activity that instigates bone repair may be the frequency of activity as opposed to its intensity alone. 

The broader impacts of this study include the scientific training of underrepresented groups, improving methodological procedures in skeletal biomechanics research, conservation of endangered primate species, and contributing to the understanding of effective physical therapy for the maintenance of bone health. The laboratory training provided under this proposal has been a major contributor to the doctoral research of three women in the anthropology graduate program at the University of Florida. Research on chemical and thermal preservational treatments on bone indicate that conventional chemical fixation have relatively minimal effects on bone hardness, which means that more expansive sampling of bone tissue in laboratory settings is justified. The utilization of calibration density instruments in CT scanning in conjunction with sampling of bone hardness allows for a direct evaluation of bone stiffness and strength from radiographic data. Activities under this award support field research in Côte d'Ivoire, and the presence of students and staff in the Taï National Forest (a World Heritage Site) tangibly discourages poaching of primates, many of which are endangered. Finally, the research from this award can inform the development of effective broad strategies for incorporation of physical therapy regimes to maintain and improve bone health.
